In-class Ex 5: Spatial Economic Interaction Models

Author

Kristine Joy Paas

Published

December 16, 2023

Modified

December 16, 2023

Setup Environment

  • spflow: R package for Spatial Economic Interaction Models
Important

We will the development version of spflow, which has major updates to syntax. (use at own risk)

It is not yet available on https://cran.r-project.org/, so we will download it from Github.

devtools::install_github("LukeCe/spflow")
pacman::p_load(tmap, sf, spdep, sp, Matrix, knitr, tidyverse, spflow)
tmap_mode("plot")
tmap_style("natural")

Loading data

mpsz_nb <- read_rds("data/rds/mpsz_nb.rds")
mpsz_flow <- read_rds("data/rds/mpsz_flow.rds")
mpsz_var <- read_rds("data/rds/mpsz_var.rds")

For our model, we will use contiguity-based neighborhood structure.

Preparing spflow objects

Creating spflow_network

mpsz_net <- spflow_network(
  id_net = "sg",
  node_neighborhood =
    nb2mat(mpsz_nb$by_contiguity),
  node_data = mpsz_var,
  node_key_column = "SZ_CODE")

mpsz_net

Creating spflow networks pairs

mpsz_net_pairs <- spflow_network_pair(
  id_orig_net = "sg",
  id_dest_net = "sg",
  pair_data = mpsz_flow,
  orig_key_column = "ORIGIN_SZ",
  dest_key_column = "DESTIN_SZ"
)

mpsz_net_pairs

Creating spflow multi-network

Important

Output must be N by N, like the dimensions of mpsz_flow

nrow(mpsz_var)^2 == nrow(mpsz_flow)
[1] TRUE
mpsz_multi_net <- spflow_network_multi(mpsz_net,
                                       mpsz_net_pairs)
mpsz_multi_net
Collection of spatial network nodes and pairs
--------------------------------------------------
Contains 1 spatial network nodes  
    With id :  sg
Contains 1 spatial network pairs  
    With id :  sg_sg

Availability of origin-destination pair information:

 ID_ORIG_NET ID_DEST_NET ID_NET_PAIR COMPLETENESS     C_PAIRS  C_ORIG  C_DEST
          sg          sg       sg_sg      100.00% 97969/97969 313/313 313/313

Correlation Analysis

Avoid having more than 2 explanatory variables that are linearly correlated. Otherwise, there will be bias in data. This is why it is important to generate a correlogram or correlation matrix to check which explanatory variables are correlated.

P_ refers to impedance

cor_formula <- log(1 + TRIPS) ~
  BUSSTOP_COUNT +
  AGE7_12 +
  AGE13_24 +
  AGE25_64 +
  SCHOOL_COUNT +
  BUSINESS_COUNT +
  RETAILS_COUNT +
  FINSERV_COUNT +
  P_(log(DISTANCE + 1))

cor_mat <- pair_cor(
  mpsz_multi_net,
  spflow_formula = cor_formula,
  add_lags_x = FALSE
)

colnames(cor_mat) <- paste0(
  substr(
    colnames(cor_mat), 1, 3), "...")

cor_image(cor_mat)

Some variables are correlated to each other so we will exclude some for them from the formula.

Examples are D_AGE13_24 and D_AGE25_64

Model Calibration

The base model

We are using Model 9 from slides (unrestricted model)

base_model <- spflow(
  spflow_formula = log(1 + TRIPS) ~
    O_(BUSSTOP_COUNT +
         AGE25_64) +
    D_(SCHOOL_COUNT +
      BUSINESS_COUNT +
      RETAILS_COUNT +
      FINSERV_COUNT)+
    P_(log(DISTANCE + 1)),
 spflow_networks = mpsz_multi_net)
base_model
--------------------------------------------------
Spatial interaction model estimated by: MLE  
Spatial correlation structure: SDM (model_9)
Dependent variable: log(1 + TRIPS)

--------------------------------------------------
Coefficients:
                          est     sd   t.stat  p.val
rho_d                   0.680  0.004  192.555  0.000
rho_o                   0.678  0.004  187.732  0.000
rho_w                  -0.396  0.006  -65.591  0.000
(Intercept)             0.410  0.065    6.266  0.000
(Intra)                 1.313  0.081   16.263  0.000
D_SCHOOL_COUNT          0.017  0.002    7.885  0.000
D_SCHOOL_COUNT.lag1     0.002  0.004    0.551  0.581
D_BUSINESS_COUNT        0.000  0.000    3.015  0.003
D_BUSINESS_COUNT.lag1   0.000  0.000   -0.249  0.804
D_RETAILS_COUNT         0.000  0.000   -0.306  0.759
D_RETAILS_COUNT.lag1    0.000  0.000    0.152  0.880
D_FINSERV_COUNT         0.002  0.000    6.787  0.000
D_FINSERV_COUNT.lag1   -0.002  0.001   -3.767  0.000
O_BUSSTOP_COUNT         0.002  0.000    6.806  0.000
O_BUSSTOP_COUNT.lag1   -0.001  0.000   -2.364  0.018
O_AGE25_64              0.000  0.000    7.336  0.000
O_AGE25_64.lag1         0.000  0.000   -2.797  0.005
P_log(DISTANCE + 1)    -0.050  0.007   -6.793  0.000

--------------------------------------------------
R2_corr: 0.6942946  
Observations: 97969  
Model coherence: Validated

D_SCHOOL_COUNT and D_BUSINESS_COUNT, the attraction is on the zone itself, not its neighbors

D_RETAILS_COUNT not significant at all for both zone and its neighbor (as p-value > 0.05)

D_FINSERV_COUNT, O_BUSSTOP_COUNT, O_AGE25_64 attractive and propulsive forces are contributed by the zone and its neighbors.

Residual diagnostics

old_par <- par(mfrow = c(1, 3),
               mar = c(2, 2, 2, 2))
spflow_moran_plots(base_model)

par(old_par)
corr_residual <- pair_cor(base_model)
colnames(corr_residual) <- substr(colnames(corr_residual), 1, 3)
cor_image(corr_residual)

The explanatory variables we used are not correlated so they are valid explanatory variables.

Note

Just change the model to generate the reports for the different models. It seems model_8 based on R-square correlation

spflow_formula <- log(1 + TRIPS) ~
  O_(BUSSTOP_COUNT +
       AGE25_64) +
  D_(SCHOOL_COUNT +
       BUSINESS_COUNT +
       RETAILS_COUNT +
       FINSERV_COUNT) +
  P_(log(DISTANCE + 1))

model_control <- spflow_control(
  estimation_method = "mle",
  model = "model_8"
)

mle_model <- spflow(
  spflow_formula,
  spflow_networks = mpsz_multi_net,
  estimation_control = model_control
)

mle_model
